column10:
SBM - Dave Pergola, Orlando Suarez, Brian Davis

Sodexo –Cindi Aki, Armond Banks, Rossana Vadala
column12:
The meeting focused on strengthening safety practices, audit alignment, and scorecard consistency between SBM and Sodexo. Both teams discussed EHS incidents and agreed to create a new “Safety” category in the complaint tracking system to enhance visibility and accountability. A mitigation plan is being developed following Kevin Schmied’s departure.

Sodexo raised concerns about internal audit results not reflecting actual site performance. To address this, KPI objectives will be realigned, and joint audits will increase from once to twice per month to improve transparency. Additionally, Orlando Suarez will coordinate internal scorecard reviews with Armond Banks to ensure both organizations measure performance using the same metrics.

Overall, the discussion reflected strong collaboration, mutual accountability, and a shared commitment to continuous improvement in safety, quality, and communication.
column13:
Cindi Aki and Rossana Vadala expressed appreciation for SBM’s improved communication and transparency regarding incidents, events, and operational updates.

Sodexo remains highly focused on safety performance and expects continued visibility and accountability through the new safety tracking initiative.

Concerns were raised about internal audit scores not aligning with on-campus performance metrics. A joint approach to auditing and KPI realignment was welcomed.

Overall, the client commended the collaborative spirit and responsiveness of SBM’s leadership team.
column14:
Dave Pergola and Orlando Suarez will finalize the mitigation plan and introduce the new “Safety” category in complaint tracking by November 30, 2025. Orlando Suarez and Rossana Vadala will begin bi-monthly joint audits to improve transparency. Orlando will also coordinate internal scorecard review sessions with Armond Banks to align metrics across both organizations by December 15, 2025.

Marvin, with support from Dave and Orlando, will deploy a QR-based service validation tool by November 14, 2025. The SBM team will complete holiday décor setup by November 21 and removal by January 11, 2026. Brian Davis and Orlando will establish a quarterly SOP review cycle and formalize pre-MBR alignment sessions by December 31, 2025. Brian will also complete a consumable stock audit and adjust par levels based on usage trends by year-end. Lastly, Orlando will review task validation processes and finalize an annual audit schedule to ensure consistent oversight and accountability by December 31, 2025.

column10: Tracey Deville, Erika Kaufman, Kevin Donaughey, John Stillson, Nikki McCall, Cody Herbert, Michael Smihosky, Brian McCalvey
column12: Overall the portfolio is satisfactory, there were some escalations out of the handful of sites - Tampa, Conroe, Ft Worth, Goodyear, Waddell. Had to create action plans for the entire portfolio to ensure those issues do not persist. All the remaining sites are meeting expectations.
column13: I’ve noted the customer concerns in the summary of the review. Will have an official QBR take place on the 14th. Client is looking at ways we can enhance service delivery across the portfolio.
column14: All regional managers have to meet with the RFM by Friday to discuss 4insite, accountability and overall performance of their respective sites. Close out any active complaints noted during the call. Move to monthly survey, joint audits cadence.

column12: The meeting was well attended with nine participants. Cigna celebrated another month with zero recordable incidents and recognized several sites for achieving over 1,000 days recordable-free. Joint audits yielded scores of 4.0 for Bloomfield, 5.0 for St. Louis, and an average of 3.6 for Arizona. Six surveys were sent and received for Arizona, with five sites earning scores of 4.0 or higher and Paseo receiving 3.75. A QAP was conducted on November 4. SBM’s scorecard KPIs were reviewed, and participants expressed appreciation for the detailed updates. Marc Normandin shared positive feedback from CBRE’s Global Engineering Director regarding the cleanliness and overall appearance of the Bloomfield site during an October visit.
column13: Cigna leadership expressed strong satisfaction with SBM’s performance, highlighting excellent safety results and positive site conditions across the portfolio. Marc Normandin relayed complimentary remarks from CBRE’s Global Engineering Director praising Bloomfield’s cleanliness and maintenance standards. Attendees also appreciated the comprehensive KPI review and the proactive communication from the SBM team.
column14:
SBM will continue to maintain its zero-incident record and focus on sustaining strong safety culture across all sites.
Joint audits will continue on schedule to ensure consistency and transparency.
The team will monitor Arizona site performance, specifically targeting improvement opportunities at Paseo to lift its audit score above 4.0.
Ongoing KPI tracking and communication updates will be maintained through monthly reviews led by Julie Bianchi.

Reviewed current safety metrics and reporting from 4insite. Data consistency and incident reporting timeliness were discussed, with an emphasis on maintaining compliance and accuracy.

Consumable Data:
Evaluated consumable tracking data from Medtronic’s dashboard and noted adjustments need to be made for Menlo Park. It is a new site so we overestimated costs, now that we have 6 months of data we can adjust the 'budget' to the correct figure.  Medtronic asked if I can include consumable spend on my SBM Scorecard commentary moving forward.

The failing site was BI Fremont. We failed our internal audits and the CSAT. We have multiple challenges at this site that we are working towards a solution with CBRE & BI. One easy fix would be adding a night custodian this would allow the floor tech to perform the FT duties. This was verbally approved by CBRE (Jim Black) /BI (Ryan Stephenson) but is not being contested because of the cost increase.

New site manager at Fremont is working on getting his BI laptop and access to their system so we can oversee the GMP program. Harjot has been requesting access since July. This is being addressed by CBRE.

Communication from the CBRE team at Fremont was also discussed. I send e-mails & follow ups that need answers and no one responds to them.
column13:
Dean wants me to invite all of the POCs for each site to these calls moving forward. This has been completed.

Dean is following up with BI to get SBM access to the elogs. John is working on it with Dean. John put together a timeline that started July 5th and he put that he and Harjot needed access.
column14:
I have set up an internal meeting on Tuesday the 11th.

We have another meeting with BI/CBRE to discuss what is needed and how we can optimize the GMP and Janitorial Program at the Fremont site. Sean, Dan, Andy & Mike are all engaged.

CBRE is scheduling this meeting.

Harjot and Zach to work on a list of who needs what access at the Fremont site.

column10: Westinghouse- Frank Butters JLL SR AD for Westinghouse, Chad Ohr Business Ops Manager
column12: We reviewed the portfolio of all 8 locations, this included trends of JA and IAs, Complaints, Report its, Good Catches, CSAT, all in depth. Call was about an hour.
column13:
During my recent engagement with Frank and Chad regarding our nuclear facilities operations for WH Columbia SC, Frank demonstrated strong interest and engagement, asking detailed follow-up questions about our cleaning processes and overall platform performance. I provided a comprehensive walkthrough of our approach, which was very well received.

Both Frank and Chad expressed high satisfaction with our platform’s capabilities and outcomes. As a result, they extended an invitation for me to serve as a guest speaker at their January 2026 review with key Westinghouse customers, a strategic opportunity to further showcase our expertise and strengthen our partnership.

Additionally, Frank acknowledged and appreciated my proactive decision to engage WH Churchill directly to ensure effective communication and maintain executive confidence, given prior challenges with information flow through JLL.

This interaction further reinforces our trusted partnership position with Westinghouse and underscores confidence in our operational excellence and leadership responsiveness.
column14: As a next step, I’ve been invited to present a Sustainability slide deck next week to Westinghouse Customer Tony and the JLL Team (Frank and team). I’m currently developing the presentation to support this discussion and further reinforce our alignment with their priorities.

column10:
Scott Kimball (SBM AD)
Rick Rivela (CBRE AD)
column12:
SR's with Rick Rivela are generally very casual and serve as an open forum for both sides to discuss challenges and opportunities. Rick mostly comes across as being a strong advocate for SBM and since the beginning has come to us directly for help with various issues CB is facing. 

In today's review, we discussed:
- some quality findings at Framingham that need to be addressed in the lead-up to a potential FDA visit (this dominated the call, due to the importance)
- the hiring of a dedicated quality manager for the Sanofi account when SBM takes over the Swiftwater GMP work,
- upcoming site visits,
column13:
While Rick's opinion was that the Framingham behavioral findings were "minor," we discussed the importance of getting them cleaned up. I explained the root cause (under-performing Supervisor) and our actions in correcting that ASAP. Rick's feedback was positive and was confident we are addressing this appropriately.

Rick also expressed a desire to have SBM conduct training with site teams on how to respond to questions in audit environments. His concern was that the Swiftwater team (not SBM managed) was unable to provide answers to simple GMP-related questions when asked by Sanofi global leaders. Rick's confidence in SBM's expertise reinforces the partnership between the two parties.
column14: Scott to continue to push for more Quality team support at Framingham in the lead-up to the FDA visit.

This will help us keep everyone in the loop and make sure we have the right staffing in place, including custodians.

column10:
This month scorecards were done on a local level. Next month for the QBR we will have a general scorecard review with all hands present. All scorecard information was also sent to Rich Darling Sr. Mgr- Mountain Region Sites Lead.

King of Prussia - Ben Ehrenberg, Paul Amato, George White Facilities Manager, Matt Zimmerman Facilities Project Associate Manager - Follow up meeting scheduled with Tracy Carroll Facility and Operations Sr. Manager for week of 11/10

North Denver Metro - Raymond Johnson, Michelle Bickford and Bridget Sangiorgi Facilities Engineer STF

Deer Creek - Raymond Johnson and Andrew Beal Facilities Manager

Huntsville - Ben Ehrenberg, Shawn Hayes, and Randal Weddington Facilities Manager

Sunnyvale - Judith Sanchez, Al Barrera, and Kathi Johanson Senior Facilities Analyst. Second supplemental meeting with Jennifer Ventura Senior Facilities Analyst
 
Littleton - Chad Devlin, Michelle Bickford, and Bruce Olsen Facilities Manager

Aero - Ben Ehrenberg and Mike McKie Facility Operations Analyst
column11: Every site scored a 5 this month
column12:
The biggest part of each of these meetings was how we are planning for the return to work initiative for Lockheed Martin starting Jan 1st. We had a team meeting last week to discuss impact and our plans at each location, which we shared this week with each respective site. 

The most impacted for us is Huntsville where we order the supplies, and we agreed to increase the contracted amount by an additional $4,000 starting in January at the latest. 

In Littleton we were a little more technology focused, since we demoed a couple of larger automated machines last month. There is a need for some additional hires at this site, and we outlined our plan to bring in additional labor.

Sunnyvale we received complements for additional projects we helped with throughout the month.

Aero we discussed the timetable for allowing us to bid on additional sites. As of now they are looking at early next year, which was pushed back from the original plan of October.

North Denver Metro we had an extremely positive meeting where we received compliments specifically at our Spine Rd location, where we had previous received a failing scorecard. Huge shout out to Raymond Johnson and all of the work he has put in with Bridget between strategizing and execution.
column13: Most of our feedback was overwhelming positive, outside of the need for additional hiring at Littleton. Lockheed Martin continues to be impressed with our ability to respond to adhere to our scope and quickly respond to Lockheed Martin's needs.
column14:
In Huntsville we submitted a quote for the increased supplies and scope, the next step is for Randal and Jeremy to provide an updated SOW + PO.

In Sunnyvale our SAM system needs an update. I engaged our 4insight team to fix and they claim they are working on it, but there is no timeline as of now. Once fixed we are making a bigger push with the help of Jennifer Ventura who will be placing new posters around campus.

In Littleton we are continuing to engage the security team about the automated equipment to make sure we are able to bring it on campus. We have sent over all the specs and are waiting for any additional questions. We completed the first round of testing for cleanroom data validation and submitted a couple changes to the 4insight team that we are waiting on responses.

column10:
Trynai Baker (JLL Soft Service & Dining Manager)
Robert Lunsford (JLL Soft Service Lead)
column12:
Highlights:
- The portfolio joint audit score for October was 93.10%, with a slight increase from the average joint audit score of 92.85% in September.  The internal audit score for October was 91.64%, slightly up from 90.72% in September.
- Zero failed audits internal or joint.
- 77.14% of our frontline associates are meeting their KPI'S
- 97.5% Training compliance
- Continued High survey score from across the portfolio with an average of 4.4
- MBIC- CSAT score 4.75
- WHBC- Continued cleaning trial being performed with routes changing cleaning delivery.  This is a prioritized cleaning model.  Major focus on quarterly ATB works this month.  Preplan for site change with building demolitions and ZWTL talks.
- GO – The newly remodeled fitness center has opened to the end user this month with a huge increase in usage in supplies and cleaning demand.  Currently quoting additional head count to offset changes.  New employee, Issac Wallace has started at the GO this month.  Issac will be filling in the vacant ops coordinator role assisting site management.
- FHCIC – Continued improvements with the previous concern with M2-M3 route.  Site manager continues to retrain and inspect area to ensure no service issues.  Challenging month coverage for reception due to call offs.  Leadership was proactive in filling in gaps to ensure proper coverage.

- BRTC – Custodian lead assisted customer request to perform a deep clean of the BRB restroom area.  This space has seen a increase in odor and the SBM team conducted an ATB project to assist the concerns.  BRTC is currently reporting to AM during transition with vacant site manager.
Low lights:
-Vacant site manager role BRTC/MBIC
- Improperly inspected equipment 
- Staff call offs IVIC
- MBIC 86% Joint audit score.  Focus on detail cleaning residue on doors.
Personal:
-One Custodian and receptionist Needed at MBIC.
-FMLA employee out at the GO.  This has been extended until November.
-FMLA employee out at FHCIC.   Employee return date January 2026.
-MBIC/BRTC open operations coordinator.
column13: The customer raised questions regarding some higher CSAT scores across the account.  Customer is aligned with all other metrics.
column14: Customer to align with POC at each site to propose a realignment on overall grading in CSAT.  They emphasized that achieving a score of a 5 should represent a significant challenge and should be harder to obtain.

We reviewed each location’s results for October and spent some time discussing the Dayton, Ohio sites, as they continue to be a key focus area. The decision to add an additional day porter is proving to be the right move based on the positive feedback NG has been sharing with both SBM and JLL.

We also talked about the new OKC location. JLL is currently working with NG to finalize the lease details. The tentative start date is November 17th, but JLL will confirm once everything is settled.

Second, we examined complaint data, which continues to show consistently low numbers. The main reason for talking through these trends was to establish a clear source of truth that reflects how our quality performance is perceived by the client in relation to the contractual scope.
column13: Overall, the feedback on our onsite service has been overwhelmingly positive, with no major concerns impacting client perceptions.
column14: We are continuing to refine the scope for two new buildings, EC1 and B2. A review is scheduled for November 10 to discuss key findings and proposed adjustments.

column10:
Mike Schroder, Senior Director of FM
Keith Hylton, Senior FM
Tristan Testagrose, FM 
Melissa De Leon, AFM
column12:
The CSAT score notably improved, with Keith Hylton scoring 4.25, citing “constant improvement over the past few months.”
The Joint Audit KPI averaged 3.91, with a family emergency on 10/31 preventing a scheduled audit that might have raised the overall score above 4.0.
Validated key corrections were completed on 10/24 (score 4.06) after a failed audit on 10/10 (score 3.79).
CBRE commended SBM’s ongoing projects and event coverage improvements; the new whiteboard system improved visibility, coordination, and task delegation.
Operational challenges included a transition to DB email accounts for compliance and an IT system upgrade, which led to some missed or delayed audits (also overlooked by CBRE). These issues have since been resolved.
Overall, it was a positive review with continued strengthening of the relationship between SBM and CBRE through open communication and steady improvement.
column13:
CBRE praised continued progress and event coverage, highlighting improvements from the new whiteboard system that enhanced coordination and scheduling efficiency.
Some concerns were raised regarding the missed audit due to the IT system upgrade and email transition, though these were acknowledged as resolved.
Feedback emphasized appreciation for transparency, steady improvements, and teamwork.
column14:
Audit Catch-Up: Validate all audits missed during the IT/email transition (Owned by site FM team – Target: within November).
Safety & Compliance: Maintain momentum toward meeting the 4.0 threshold; ensure future audits remain on schedule (Owned by Keith Hylton).
System Stability: Continue monitoring the DB email and IT systems to prevent recurrence of missed audits (Owned by SBM/CBRE joint oversight).
CSAT Tracking: Maintain and document customer satisfaction progress monthly (Owned by Melissa De Leon).

column10:
John Ellis 
David Campos
column12: safety: 158 recordable-free days achieved; discussed outcomes from the 2nd Safety Committee meeting focused on cross-contamination of chemicals.HR: Staffing level at 99.2%, with recruiting described as active and productive. 9 job offers were made at the recent job fair, which was deemed a success.Projects: Preparations are underway for the BSB Fitness Deep Clean scheduled toward the end of the month.Operations: All new hires are being trained immediately upon onboarding to ensure long-term retention and process consistency. Support teams successfully managed special events and adjusted schedules as needed.4insite Performance: Audit scores remained above target, with 179 to-dos created and 172 closed, indicating high task closure efficiency.
column13:
CBRE shared positive feedback recognizing SBM’s responsiveness, strong staffing levels, and readiness for major cleaning projects.
They expressed appreciation for proactive communication and team flexibility during multiple special events.
A single compliment was logged through 4insite, reflecting client satisfaction.
No formal concerns or complaints were raised during the review.
column14: The team will finalize and execute the BSB Fitness Deep Clean plan by the end of November. HR and site leadership will continue employee engagement initiatives, including Thanksgiving meals for both AM and PM shifts later this month. SBM will also partner with CBRE to define and formalize measurable MBR output metrics in early December. Finally, the site FM will maintain oversight of audit performance and task closure rates to ensure ongoing operational consistency.

column10: Edina Lemo and Jim Moore
column12:
As JLL has only recently assumed ownership of the contract, this review served as a high-level orientation and introduction to the portfolio. Discussion centered around Las Colinas (LC) and West Des Moines, IA locations.
At Las Colinas, the team reviewed the breezeway pacers, which are not within SBM’s scope, and clarified ongoing responsibilities.
In West Des Moines, the focus was on the failed SAT previously received from Briget, who has since remained with CBRE on the WF Retail side.
The meeting also included updates on the transition progress, early positive impressions of SBM’s team performance, and the goal of strengthening site partnerships under JLL’s new management.
column13:
JLL shared that they are already seeing positive outcomes from SBM’s involvement at Las Colinas, noting visible improvements within the first month.
Cynthia was specifically commended for her leadership and collaboration.
JLL acknowledged that while they are still transitioning their newly acquired team, they are pleased with SBM’s team and the partnership potential.
In Des Moines, they reiterated the need for stronger collaboration and communication moving forward.
While still cautious with Jim and Edina, JLL appears open to continued partnership and has shown early signs of trust-building.
column14:
SBM will continue reinforcing positive outcomes and partnership wins during the JLL transition period. The team will clarify the scope at Las Colinas, ensuring alignment on responsibilities.
At West Des Moines, SBM will focus on rebuilding partnership trust and improving communication under Jason’s oversight of all IA locations.
Ongoing engagement and transparency will remain priorities to strengthen collaboration with Jim, Edina, and the wider JLL team.

The October scorecard meeting was brief, about 15 minutes, but very positive. The results showed good performance across all sides, with a 4.67 average score for the account: 
Cambridge: 5.00
RTP Pharma: 4.38

column13: CBRE leadership acknowledged that the current scores now better reflect the actual quality of work being delivered. Timothy O' Donnell specifically noted that earlier in the year, there were concerns that the data didn't align with on-the-ground performance. He expressed appreciation for the progress made and the improved accuracy of reporting.

column12: Overall, all sites reported strong feedback and strong operations. Teams are proactively preparing for winter conditions and aligning on upcoming projects focused on employee engagement and enhanced building care. Even though one site is slightly short on staffing, service levels remain stable through effective planning and team collaboration. The collective focus on readiness, communication, and ownership continues to strengthen site performance across the portfolio.
column13: Customer feedback across all sites has been very positive. Clients have recognized the teams' consistency, attention to detail, and responsiveness to requests. Several highlighted noticeable improvements in overall presentation and communication. The feedback reflects strong collaboration between site teams and leadership, reinforcing confidence in our service quality and daily execution.

column12:
The recent review of joint audits and scorecards across all buildings reflected a strong alignment between operational execution and client expectations. The comprehensive audit coverage has allowed us to identify cross-site trends, reinforce consistency, and ensure that every building meets the same high standard of quality. 
The targeted audit approach continues to be a key driver in performance improvement. By focusing on high-impact areas and recurring findings, we've been able to address root causes rather than symptoms-enhancing both efficiency and long-term sustainability. 
In addition, the route adjustments and on-hand training sessions implemented this quarter have proven effective in increasing visibility, optimizing labor distribution, and promoting team accountability. These actions have not only improved daily execution but also strengthened our overall readiness for audits and VIP visits.
column13: Consistency has been a key differentiator across all states, reflected in both performance and communication. JLL and J&J have expressed strong satisfaction with the steady progress and visible improvements in service delivery. They remain encouraged by the team's commitment and are supportive of continuing to push forward with new initiatives that strengthen quality, efficiency, and the overall customer experience.
